engineering_design_principles.mechanism: Deoxyribose sugar provides a stable and durable framework for DNA, allowing it to maintain its structure and integrity within the cell.
The geometry and design of deoxyribose and the double helix structure of DNA enable efficient and accurate storage and transmission of genetic information.
The absence of one oxygen atom in deoxyribose results in a more stable and compact structure, allowing DNA to pack tightly into the cell.
Phosphate groups link deoxyribose sugar molecules together, forming a double helix structure with bases in the center, enabling DNA to store genetic information in the form of base pair sequences.
